introduction.p: In the last two sections, we talked about how to solve for all possible solutions to a trig equation. By knowing the set of all possible solutions to a trig equation, we can determine which of those solutions are in a given interval (e.g. [0, 2\pi]). The methods used for solving trig equations on an interval is essentially the same as finding the set of all possible solutions, with the only difference being that we need to also determine which integer values of k will make the solutions lie in the interval. We will also discuss how algebraic techniques such as factoring and substitution are used to solve even more general trig equations such as \sin^2(\theta)+2\sin(\theta)+1 = 0.

subsection.title: Finding Solutions on a Given Interval
subsection.p: The next example addresses the problem of finding a finite number of solutions on a specified interval.

statement.p: Solve the trigonometric equation 2\sin(3\theta)=1 for all values of \theta in the interval [-\pi,\pi].

solution.p: We solved this equation for all possible values of \theta in the previous section. We found that \theta = \frac{\pi}{18}+\frac{2\pi}{3} k \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \theta = \frac{5\pi}{18} + \frac{2\pi}{3} k \hspace{.25in} \text{ where } k \text{ is any integer}

To find values of \theta in the interval [-\pi,\pi], we must test values of k. To better organize our work, we will create a "k-table" where we can keep track of different values of k, the angle \theta they yield, and whether or not that angle is in the interval [-\pi,\pi].

Notice that for both positive and negative values of k, we stopped as soon as we reached a value of \theta that was outside of the interval [-\pi,\pi]. This is because for positive values of k, \theta was getting larger, so once \theta was greater than \pi it would always be greater than \pi. Similarly, when k was negative, \theta was getting more negative, so once it was less than -\pi it would always be less than -\pi. Therefore, from the table we can see that there are exactly six solutions in the interval [-\pi,\pi]: -\frac{11\pi}{18}, \ -\frac{7\pi}{18}, \ \frac{\pi}{18}, \ \frac{5\pi}{18}, \ \frac{13\pi}{18}, \ \frac{17\pi}{18}

subsection.title: Solving Trig Equations Using Algebraic Techniques
subsection.p: We can also use more complex algebraic techniques, such as factoring and substitution, to solve trigonometric equations. Consider the function f(x) = 2x^2+x. If you were asked to solve f(x) = 0, you could use algebra to arrive at two solutions.
First, we set \ 2x^2+x = 0 \ and factor, which gives us x(2x + 1) = 0

Now, since the terms \ x \ and \ 2x+1 \ multiply together to equal 0, we know that either \ x=0 \ or \ 2x+1=0 \ . Therefore, we get the two solutions x=0 \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} x=-\frac{1}{2}
Following the same steps, we can solve the equation f(\theta) = 0 where f(\theta) = 2\sin^2(\theta) + \sin(\theta). We get that

Like before, we have two terms that multiply together to get 0. Therefore, we know that either \sin(\theta) = 0 \hspace{.25in} \text{ or } \hspace{.25in} 2\sin(\theta) + 1 = 0 We must now solve each of these equations to get a complete set of solutions.

Solving the equation \ \sin(\theta) = 0 \ gives us the solutions ...,-\pi,0,\pi,2\pi,... which can be represented as the solution set \theta = \pi k \hspace{.25in} \text{where } k \text{ is any integer}

Solving the equation \ 2\sin(\theta) + 1 = 0 we get \displaystyle \sin(\theta) = -\frac{1}{2} , which gives us the solution set \theta = \frac{7\pi}{6}+2\pi k \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \theta = \frac{11\pi}{6} + 2\pi k \hspace{.25in} \text{ where } k \text{ is any integer}
